This study investigates the performance regulation and mechanism of citric acid on the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst. The CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst exhibits a denitrification conversion rate exceeding 90 % within the temperature range of 217–517°C, with a significantly broader working temperature window. Additionally, it demonstrates excellent N2 selectivity and superior resistance to water and sulfur. Through a series of characterization methods, the physical and chemical properties of the catalyst were analyzed. The results indicate that the complexation of an appropriate amount of citric acid with Ce and W can refine the grain size, increase the specific surface area, and provide more acidic sites, significantly improving the adsorption properties. Moreover, the addition of citric acid during the preparation process can promote the electron transfer between active elements, increase the oxygen vacancy content, and enhance the catalyst's redox properties. Graphical Abstract Keywords Denitration NH3-SCR Citric acid CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NOx) are one of the major atmospheric pollutants responsible for acid rain, photochemical smog, and the greenhouse effect. Their strong toxicity seriously threatens human health and damages the Earth's ecology [1–3]. In terms of controlling NOx emissions in flue gas, Selective Catalytic Reduction (SCR) technology is currently the mainstream approach [4,5]. In high-temperature, high-dust flue gas treatment processes, V2O5-WO3(MoO3)/TiO2 high-temperature denitration catalysts are commonly used, as they have high catalytic activity and good resistance to poisoning by SO2 and H2O [6–8]. However, these catalysts have a narrow temperature range (350–450°C), making it difficult to adapt to flue gas temperature fluctuations, and the active component V2O5 is toxic [9,10]. Therefore, the development of denitration catalysts is moving toward improving denitration efficiency and broadening the reaction temperature window. Ce-based catalytic materials have received widespread attention in the application of SCR catalysts. CeO2, due to the electronic transfer between Ce4+/Ce3+ that forms oxygen vacancies, can enhance the redox performance of the catalyst [11–13]. At the same time, W-modified Ce-based catalysts have been widely studied from various aspects. First, WO3 can regulate the acidic sites in the catalyst. Chen et al. [14] prepared Ce/TiO2 and W-Ce/TiO2 catalysts by impregnation, and the study found that the addition of WO3 provided more acidic sites on the catalyst surface, accelerating the reaction between NH4NO3 and NO, while also expanding the catalyst's activity at low temperatures. Iwasaki et al. [15] found through research that, compared with a mixture of WO3/ZrO2 and CeO2, WO3/CeO2 catalysts exhibited higher SCR reaction activity. This is because the interaction between active Ce centers and WO3 improved the redox performance, as well as the atomic-level proximity and the large number of acid-redox interfaces. Secondly, highly dispersed W is beneficial for enhancing the overall catalytic performance of the catalyst. Zhang et al. [16] found through research that dispersed WO3 is beneficial for improving catalytic activity, while crystalline WO3 inhibits catalytic activity. Finally, the synergistic effect between WO3 and CeO2 is beneficial for improving denitration performance. Liu et al. [17] found through research that doping W into Ce-based catalysts activated adjacent oxygen atoms on the Ce-based catalyst, thereby promoting the reducibility of Ce sites, making them more active in the NH3-SCR reaction. At the same time, there is a significant interaction between CeO2 and WO3 at the Ce-O-W interface, and the metal (Ce and W) oxides are more dispersed on TiO2, forming solid solutions at the oxide interfaces. These strong synergistic effects generate more Ce3+ ions, surface-active oxygen, and acid sites, all of which are the main active sites for the NH3-SCR reaction, making the SCR reaction more likely to occur. Many studies have shown that introducing organic additives during the preparation process to modify catalysts can improve their redox performance, surface acidity, and promote strong interactions between active components, with citric acid modification being significant. For example, He et al. [18] used tartaric acid, citric acid, and oxalic acid as structure-directing agents to synthesize different forms of WO3 nanoparticles, increasing the surface Ce3+ content and the proportion of adsorbed oxygen Oα, thereby improving the redox performance of the catalyst. Zhang et al. [19] synthesized a series of Fe3+-doped MnCeOx catalysts using the citric acid method and found that the citric acid method more easily promotes electron transfer between active elements, resulting in a higher concentration of Mn4+ and generating more active oxygen beneficial for the NH3-SCR reaction. Xiong et al. [20] studied the effect of citric acid content on the structure and redox performance of magnetic iron-cerium-tungsten mixed oxide catalysts prepared by microwave-assisted citric acid sol-gel method. They found that when the molar ratio of citric acid/(Fe + Ce + W) increased from 0.25 to 1.0, the concentrations of Fe3+ and Fe2+ on the catalyst surface both increased, while the increase in citric acid content was favorable for improving the SCR reaction rate normalized by the surface area, making the catalyst exhibit higher resistance to SO2 and H2O poisoning. Yang et al. [21] used the citric acid complexation impregnation method to prepare Mn-Ce-Co honeycomb catalysts supported on activated carbon and found that the synergistic effect between citric acid and the ternary metals made the catalyst prepared by the citric acid complexation impregnation method have excellent redox performance and a higher number of acidic sites. Citric acid modification, by increasing the acidity of the catalyst and introducing CeO2 sacrificial sites, improved the catalytic performance of the catalyst, weakened its adsorption capacity for SO2, and enhanced its tolerance to SO2. In the previous work of this research group, a CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst with a denitration efficiency of over 90 % in the temperature range of 241°C–504°C was developed [22]. Further studies found that citric acid modification could further improve the denitration performance of this catalyst. However, there are limited reports on the citric acid-modified CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst in existing research. To clarify the mechanism of citric acid modification on the denitration performance of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst, this paper used XRD, BET, XPS, SEM, TEM, H2-TPR, NH3-TPD, and In-situ DRIFTs methods to investigate the effects of citric acid on the denitration performance, catalyst morphology, surface acidity, redox ability, and catalytic mechanism of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst, thereby providing theoretical and technical support for the development and application of Ce-based catalysts. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Catalyst preparation The CeO2-WO3/TiO2-n catalyst was prepared using a co-precipitation method. The preparation steps were as follows: 1.95 g ammonium metatungstate (H28N6O41W12), 30.11 g cerium chloride heptahydrate (CeCl3·7 H2O), and 30 g titanium dioxide were sequentially added to a beaker containing deionized water and stirred continuously for 30 min. After adding a certain amount of citric acid to the catalyst solution, ammonia water was added dropwise to adjust the pH of the solution to 9–10, and the mixture was stirred for 3 h before filtering. The resulting filter cake was washed with water three times, then dried at 70°C for 24 h and calcined at 500℃ in a muffle furnace for 3 h to obtain the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-n catalyst, where n represents the mass percentage of citric acid added to the catalyst, with n values of 0 %, 3 %, 6 %, and 9 %. The preparation process of the catalyst is shown in Fig. 1. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations In this experiment, the phase and crystal structure of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-n catalyst were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD) with a D8 ADVANCE analyzer produced by German Brooke AXS Co., Ltd. employing Cu Kα radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm). The scanning covered angles from 10° ∼ 90° at a rate of 10° min−1. Surface morphology was examined using a Hitachi SU8020 ultra-high resolution field emission scanning electron microscope (SEM), capable of magnifications ranging from 3 ∼ 800,000 times. The SEM's X-ray spectrometer allowed elemental analysis from B5 ∼ U92, with an energy resolution of 130 eV. The fine structure image of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-n catalyst was obtained. The microstructure of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-n catalyst was scrutinized using a Japanese JEM-2100F transmission electron microscope (TEM), which featured a point resolution of 0.23 nm, magnifications of 50 ∼ 1000000, and an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. The nano-scale micro-analysis of the catalyst was carried out using a high-resolution lattice fringe image. The relationship between the active phase composition and its correlation with catalytic performance of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-n catalyst was analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), and the correlation between the reaction mechanism and the composition-structure-activity of the catalyst was investigated. We utilized an excitation source of Al Kα (1486.6 eV), with an acceleration power of 150 W, and the binding energy of C 1 s (284.6 eV) serving as the internal standard. The peak fitting was executed using XPS Peak software. The specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-n catalyst were quantified through N2 adsorption/desorption analysis, conducted on an ASAP 2460 analyzer (Micromeritics, USA) at a temperature of 196 °C (liquid nitrogen temperature). Prior to N2 adsorption, the catalyst sample was degassed at 400 °C for 4 h. The BET equation was applied to determine the surface area in the partial pressure range of 0.0 ∼ 0.35. The surface acidity of CeO2-WO3/TiO2-n catalyst was assessed using ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) test, performed on an AutoChemII2920 instrument produced by American Mac. Test conditions included weighing 120 mg of the samples, which were placed in a U-shaped quartz tube. The temperature was programmed to escalate from room temperature to 160 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1. After dry pretreatment, a helium gas flow (50 mL min−1) purged the system for 2 h before cooling to 50 °C. The mixture of NH3/He (50 mL min−1) was then introduced for 1 h to achieve saturation. Subsequently, a helium purge (50 mL min−1) was conducted for 1 h to remove weakly adsorbed NH3 on the surface. The sample was heated to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 under a continuous helium flow (50 mL min−1), with gas detection performed by the TCD. The redox capability of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-n catalyst was evaluated using a temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR) test. The test was performed with an AutoChemII2920 instrument produced by American Mike Company. In this assay, 70 mg samples were weighed and placed in a U-shaped quartz tube. The sample was dried from room temperature to 200 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1 under a helium flow (50 mL min−1) for 2 h, followed by cooling to 50 °C. A 10 % H2/Ar gas mixture (50 mL min−1) was introduced for 30 min until a stable baseline was achieved. The sample was subsequently heated to 800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 in 10 % H2/Ar gas flow (50 mL min−1), with extracted gases detected by the TCD. In situ Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectroscopy (In situ DRIFTs) of NH3 adsorption on CeO2-WO3/TiO2-n catalyst samples was carried out using a German Bruker Tensor 27 FT-IR spectrometer. The sample was pretreated with N2 at 200 °C for 1 h to remove physically adsorbed water. During the cooling phase, the background spectrum for each sample is obtained. Then, each sample was saturated with a 500 ppm NH3-N2 mixture at room temperature. Finally, the background spectrum was subtracted from each measurement before recording the final spectrum. 2.3 Measurement of catalyst activity In this experiment, the activity of the catalyst sample (5 mL of catalyst particles with a particle size of 0.25 ∼ 0.425 mm) was evaluated in a fixed bed catalytic reactor (stainless steel shell, inner diameter 12 mm). The fixed nitric oxide detector (ES10B10-NO, measurement range: 0 ∼ 1000 ppm, working environment: temperature 0 ∼ 500 ℃, humidity ≤ 95 % RH, response time 30 s, resolution 1 ppm) was used to measure the inlet and outlet NO concentration. The gases from the high-purity gas cylinders, including oxygen, nitrogen, ammonia, and nitric oxide, were regulated through a mass flow controller after pressure reduction and thorough mixing. The gas mixture, simulating typical industrial flue gas, contained 600 ppm NO, 600 ppm NH3, 5 vol% O2, and equilibrium gas (N2), corresponding to a GHSV of 36000 h−1. The efficiency of catalyst denitration and N2 selectivity were calculated based on these operational conditions: (1) NO Conversion = [ NO ] in − NO out [ NO ] in × 100 % (2) N 2 Selectivity = 1 − 2 [ N 2 O ] [ NH 3 ] in − NH 3 out + [ NO ] in − NO out × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Morphology and structure of catalysts 3.1.1 XRD, BET surface area and pore morphology Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalysts before and after citric acid addition. From the figure, the diffraction peaks of cubic fluorite-type CeO2 and anatase-type TiO2 can be observed. However, WO3 does not show distinct diffraction peaks. It may be that the content of WO3 is low, and its diffraction peak cannot be displayed in the XRD spectrum [23]; Or the complexation of citric acid with Ce and W may cause W6+ to be incorporated into the CeO2 lattice, forming a Ce-O-W solid solution structure, which promotes the interaction between the active components [19]. After citric acid modification, the diffraction peak of CeO2 at 28.6° shifts to a higher angle, and according to the Bragg equation, the lattice parameter of CeO2 in the citric acid-modified catalyst decreases ( Table 1), further confirming that W6+ metal ions were successfully doped into the CeO2 lattice. Among the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst, the interplanar distance of CeO2 is the smallest, indicating that the addition of 6 % citric acid maximally promotes the shrinkage of the CeO2 lattice. Many studies have shown that smaller crystallite sizes help improve the denitration performance of the catalyst. In addition, for the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst, the width of the CeO2 diffraction peak remains almost unchanged but its intensity weakens, suggesting that the complexation of citric acid with Ce and W reduces the crystallinity and/or improves the dispersion of CeO2, which is beneficial for increasing the specific surface area of the catalyst and/or enhancing the SCR reaction sites. In previous studies, researchers concluded that the NH3-SCR reaction mainly occurs on the surface of the catalyst, and micropores and mesopores can provide a larger internal surface area and/or pore volume in the SCR reaction, resulting in a larger BET surface area, which is beneficial for improving the denitration performance of the catalyst [24]. Therefore, we tested the pore structure characteristics of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalysts before and after citric acid addition through N2 adsorption-desorption measurements, as shown in Fig. 3. According to the IUPAC classification, the resulting samples' isotherms are closely related to type IV N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms, with a hysteresis loop of type H3, indicating the presence of slit-like mesoporous structures in the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-n catalyst in the range of 2–50 nm. At the same time, the isotherm at high P/P0 is similar to type II, indicating the formation of macropores (>50 nm) and mesopores (2–50 nm) in the catalyst [25]. From Fig. 3(b), the wide pore size distribution of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst before and after citric acid addition can be clearly observed. The detailed results of the BET surface area and pore structure of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst before and after citric acid addition are shown in Table 1. The results indicate that citric acid modification helps increase the BET surface area of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst and improves the pore structure. When the citric acid addition is 6 %, the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst has the smallest average pore size (12.71 nm) and the largest BET surface area (43.71 m²/g) and pore volume (0.261 cm³/g), which is consistent with the XRD analysis results. 3.1.2 Morphological analysis The SEM images of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalysts before and after citric acid addition are shown in Fig. 4. In Fig. 4(a), the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst particles have attachments of varying sizes on their surface, which are attributed to CeO2 and a small amount of WO3 loaded onto TiO2, with both components dispersed on the TiO2 support in an amorphous or microcrystalline form. After citric acid addition, the size and dispersion of the attached particles of the active components on the TiO2 support become significantly more uniform. In Fig. 4(c), the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst shows even smaller particle sizes of the attached active components on the surface, and combined with the XRD results, it can be seen that the active components CeO2 and WO3 are more uniformly dispersed and wrapped on the surface of the TiO2 support. However, when the citric acid content is increased to 9 %, the active components on the TiO2 support surface undergo agglomeration again. Fig. 5 shows the TEM images of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalysts before and after citric acid addition. From the figure, it can be seen that the active components CeO2 and WO3 in the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst are small particles distributed on the surface of the TiO2 support. After citric acid addition, the particle size of the active components on the TiO2 support surface becomes finer, and the dispersion is more uniform. Especially for the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst, the dispersion and compactness of the active components on the surface are optimal, with most of the active components wrapped on the TiO2 support, showing uniform particle distribution and similar particle sizes, which is consistent with the SEM results. The HRTEM high-resolution images of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalysts before and after citric acid addition are shown in Fig. 6, from which, the CeO2{111} and WO3{200} crystal planes can be clearly observed. First, looking at the CeO2{111} crystal plane, the lattice fringe spacing of CeO2{111} in the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst is d = 0.3124 nm. After adding citric acid, the lattice fringe spacing of CeO2{111} in the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-3 % catalyst gradually decreases (d = 0.3120 nm). As the citric acid content increases, the lattice fringe spacing of CeO2{111} in the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst becomes d = 0.3108 nm, showing a significant decrease. When the citric acid content continues to increase, the lattice fringe spacing of CeO2{111} in the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-9 % catalyst (d = 0.3112 nm) shows an increasing trend again. Next, looking at the WO3{200} crystal plane, as the citric acid content increases, the WO3{200} lattice spacing gradually decreases. The lattice spacing of the WO3{200} crystal plane in the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % and CeO2-WO3/TiO2-9 % catalysts is almost the same. In summary, this suggests that when 6 % citric acid is added, the complexation of citric acid with Ce and W effectively inhibits the lattice growth of CeO2 and WO3, which helps to maximize the dispersion of the catalyst and increase the specific surface area, consistent with the XRD and BET results. 3.2 Surface properties of catalysts To study the effect of citric acid modification on the surface elements of the catalyst, surface element analysis of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-n catalysts was performed, and the results are shown in Fig. 7. Fig. 7(a) shows the Ce 3d XPS spectra of the different citric acid-modified catalysts. Combined with the data of the Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) ratio in the figure, it can be observed that with the increase in citric acid addition, the Ce3+/(Ce3++Ce4+) ratio in the catalyst gradually increases, and the Ce3+ ratio reaches the highest value of 0.34 in the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst. This indicates that citric acid promotes the conversion of some Ce4+ to Ce3+ on the catalyst surface (Ce4+↔Ce3++Cat-[O]). At the same time, combined with the XRD and SEM results, citric acid modification promotes the sufficient atomic-level contact between CeO2 and WO3, enhancing the electron transfer between the active elements, which leads to a higher concentration of Ce3+ on the catalyst surface and active oxygen that is beneficial for the NH3-SCR reaction. In Fig. 7(b), two distinct O 1 s peaks appear, with binding energies around 532.2 eV, attributed to chemisorbed oxygen Oα, and around 530.0 eV, attributed to lattice oxygen Oβ. After citric acid addition, the Oα peak shifts to a higher binding energy, indicating that some Oβ is transforming into Oα, promoting the generation of more Oα. The Oα ratio in the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst increases from 0.221 to 0.339. This is because the complexation of citric acid with Ce and W promotes electron transfer between the active elements, thus releasing more surface-adsorbed oxygen Oα, which is favorable for the formation of more NH4 + and NO2. The citric acid modification also improves the dispersion of CeO2 and WO3 on the TiO2 surface, promotes the increase in the catalyst's specific surface area, enhances oxygen mobility, and increases the adsorption sites for NOx and NH3. According to the W 4 f XPS spectra in Fig. 7(c), it can be seen that the W 4 f spectrum has two peaks centered at 35.9 eV and 38.0 eV, which correspond to W 4 f7/2 and W 4 f5/2, respectively. The W 4 f binding energy of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst is the lowest, indicating that the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst surface may contain more W5+ species. The W 4 f spectra of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-n catalysts can be deconvoluted into two doublet pairs, corresponding to W5+ and W6+. From the figure, it can be observed that the surface W5+/(W5+ + W6+) ratio is highest in the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst. The higher W5+ ratio indicates an increase in surface unsaturation, which is beneficial for providing additional oxygen vacancies on the catalyst [26]. The above analysis shows that citric acid modification affects the valence state distribution and oxygen content of the surface active elements of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst. When 6 % citric acid is added, the catalyst surface has the highest proportion of Ce3+ and W5+, as well as the highest content of chemisorbed oxygen, significantly enhancing oxygen mobility and providing more reaction sites, which is one of the key reasons for the improvement of the catalyst's denitration performance. 3.3 Acidic sites distribution of catalysts In the NH3-SCR reaction, the adsorption of NH3 on the active sites of the catalyst surface is the primary reaction, and there are two forms: one is NH3 adsorbed on the Brønsted acid sites, forming NH4 +; the other is NH3 adsorbed on the Lewis acid sites, forming a coordination state of NH3 [27]. Therefore, it is necessary to study the acid density, acid strength, and the distribution of acid strength on the catalyst surface. NH3-TPD tests were performed on the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-n catalysts, and the results are shown in Fig. 8 and Table 2. From the NH3-TPD spectra in Fig. 8, it can be seen that all four groups of catalysts exhibit distinct desorption peaks corresponding to weak acid and strong acid sites. The introduction of citric acid creates a noticeable medium-strong acid desorption peak around 270°C in the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst. In addition, after the introduction of citric acid, the peak intensity of the strong acid desorption peak around 515°C gradually increases, indicating that citric acid modification significantly increases the NH3 adsorption on the strong acid sites. As the citric acid content increases from 0 % to 6 %, from Table 2, it can be seen that the NH3 adsorption on the strong acid sites of the catalyst surface increases from 680.34 μmol·g−1 to 824.13 μmol·g−1. Combined with the XPS results, this suggests that citric acid modification increases the surface unsaturation of the catalyst and releases more acidic sites, thereby adsorbing more NH3 to promote the SCR reaction cycle. However, when the citric acid content continues to increase, the desorption peak temperature of the strong acid sites shifts to a higher temperature, the probable reason is that when the amount of citric acid exceeds a certain threshold, both the surface unsaturation degree of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-9 % catalyst and the dispersion of CeO2 decrease, reducing the adsorption of NH3 at the Brønsted acid sites on the catalyst surface. 3.4 Redox properties of catalysts 3.4.1 H2-TPR In the NH3-SCR reaction, the redox performance of the catalyst is crucial for the catalytic cycle. H2-TPR is an effective method to evaluate the reduction performance of CeO2-WO3/TiO2-n catalysts [28]. To investigate the effect of citric acid modification on the reduction ability of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst, H2-TPR characterization was performed on the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-n catalysts, and the results are shown in Fig. 9 and Table 3. In the H2-TPR spectrum of Fig. 9, the reduction peak at 500–550°C corresponds to the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+, while the reduction peak at 750–800°C corresponds to the reduction of W6+ to W5+. From the figure, it can be seen that the introduction of citric acid promotes the shift of the Ce4+ → Ce3+ and W6+ → W5+ reduction peaks to lower temperatures. The change in the position of the reduction peaks is related to the variation in crystal size and surface structural bond lengths [29,30]. The shift of the reduction peaks to lower temperatures indicates that the activity of chemisorbed oxygen becomes stronger, which is beneficial for the reduction of surface species on the catalyst. At the same time, combined with the analysis in Table 3, the H2 consumption for the Ce4+ → Ce3+ reduction process in the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst increases from 2.69 to 3.22 mmol·g−1, and the H2 consumption for the W6+ → W5+ reduction process increases from 0.99 to 1.19 mmol·g−1. This indicates that the complexation of citric acid with Ce and W increases the exposed amount and exposed area of CeO2 and WO3, while enhancing the reduction ability of Ce4+ → Ce3+ and W6+ → W5+. This shows that citric acid modification increases the number of active species on the catalyst surface, which is beneficial for providing additional oxygen vacancies on the catalyst and promoting the SCR reaction, consistent with the XPS results. 3.4.2 O2-TPD O2-TPD tests were performed on CeO2-WO3/TiO2-n catalysts to explore the effects of citric acid modification on the oxygen storage capacity and surface reactive oxygen species of CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalysts. The results are presented in Fig. 10 and Table 4. For the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-n catalysts, oxygen desorption peaks below 300 ℃ can be attributed to active chemisorbed oxygen or active lattice oxygen on the catalyst surface, while peaks in the range of 300 ∼ 600 ℃ correspond to surface or subsurface lattice oxygen [31]. After citric acid modification, the intensity of the reactive oxygen species peaks on the catalyst surface increased significantly, indicating that citric acid strongly promotes the activation of surface oxygen and enhances the mobility of oxygen on the catalyst surface, which is consistent with the findings from XPS analysis. Notably, the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst exhibited the largest peak area for surface reactive oxygen species (Table 4), suggesting a higher concentration of reactive oxygen species. This indicates that citric acid modification enhanced the redox capacity of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst, a conclusion supported by H2-TPR. 3.5 NO adsorption capacity of catalysts In order to explore how citric acid modification affects the NO adsorption capacity of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst, NO-TPD tests were performed on the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-n catalyst. The findings are illustrated in Fig. 11. For the unmodified CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst, a single prominent NOx desorption centered at 337.8 ℃ was observed. In contrast, the citric acid modified catalyst demonstrated two distinct NOx desorption. The low-temperature peaks correspond to the physical adsorption of NOx and monodentate nitrate species, while the high-temperature peaks represent the decomposition of bridged nitrates and bidentate nitrates with higher thermal stability [32]. Most NOx forms stable nitrates on the surface of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst, which cannot participate in reactions at low temperatures. Therefore, the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst displays lower NO oxidation activity and reduced SCR performance. The citric acid modification enhances the diversity and extent of NOx adsorption, promoting the formation of various nitrates on the catalyst surface, thereby improving its denitrification efficiency. 3.6 Reaction mechanism inference (In-situ DRIFTs) According to the above analysis, the catalytic activity of CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalysts is influenced by various factors, one of the main reasons being the change in acidic sites. The SCR reaction is a heterogeneous gas-solid reaction catalyzed by a solid catalyst, requiring the catalyst to have sufficient active sites to adsorb the reacting gases. In order to study the changes in the adsorption properties of CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalysts during the low-temperature NH3-SCR reaction and explore the mechanism of catalyst activity variation, in this section, In-situ DRIFTs was used to investigate the relationship between the reacting gases (NH3 and NO) and the catalyst surface. 3.6.1 Adsorption of NH3 In order to further clarify the nature of ad-NH3 on the surface of CeO2-WO3/TiO2-n catalysts, we collected In-situ DRIFTs spectra of NH3 adsorption at different temperatures, and the results are shown in Fig. 12. From the spectra of CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalysts, the bands at 1342 cm−1 and 1141 cm−1 correspond to the coordinated NH3 groups adsorbed on Lewis acid sites, while the bands at 1625 cm−1, 1420 cm−1, and 1388 cm−1 correspond to the NH4 + ions adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites (Fig. 12(a)). From the spectra of CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst, the bands at 1342 cm−1 and 1141 cm−1 correspond to the coordinated NH3 groups adsorbed on Lewis acid sites, while the bands at 1594 cm−1 and 1420 cm−1 correspond to the NH4 + ions adsorbed on Brønsted acid sites (Fig. 12(b)) [33]. As the temperature increases, the intensity of the bands corresponding to the Brønsted acid sites generally weakens significantly due to the conversion and desorption of the adsorbed NH3. When the temperature reaches 400°C, the intensity of the bands at 1625 cm−1 and 1594 cm−1 in both figures decreases significantly, almost disappearing, while the intensity of the bands corresponding to the Lewis acid sites shows no significant change, indicating that NH4 + ions are desorbed at high temperatures, and Brønsted acid sites are thermally unstable, whereas Lewis acid sites exhibit higher thermal stability. By comparison, it can be observed that the peak intensities for the Lewis acid site (1342 cm−1) and the Brønsted acid site (1420 cm−1) on the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst are significantly higher than those on the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst, indicating that the acid amount on CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % is greater than that on CeO2-WO3/TiO2, which is consistent with the NH3-TPD results. At 400°C, most of the peaks on the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst spectrum almost disappear, while the Lewis acid peak at 1342 cm−1 in the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst spectrum remains clearly visible, indicating that the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst has more surface active sites, or that the surface adsorption capacity of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst is weaker, meaning the introduction of citric acid is beneficial for the adsorption and activation of NH3 molecules. In summary, based on the NH3 adsorption characteristics on CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % and CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalysts, it can be concluded that the addition of 6 % citric acid significantly enhanced the quantity and strength of both Lewis and Brønsted acid sites, making the surface acidity of CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst stronger, as well as improving NH3 adsorption and activation capabilities, which is favorable for enhancing the denitration performance of the NH3-SCR reaction. 3.6.2 NO+O2 co-adsorption To understand the effect of citric acid modification on the microscopic process of the NH3-SCR reaction on CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst, it is necessary to identify the types of adsorbed species on the catalyst surface. Therefore, NO+O2 in-situ co-adsorption experiments were conducted on CeO2-WO3/TiO2-n catalysts, and the results are shown in Fig. 13. The CeO2-WO3/TiO2-n catalysts were exposed to a NO+O2 mixed gas (500 ppm NO + 5 % O2, N2 balance) at room temperature, and multiple infrared vibration signals appeared between 1000 and 2000 cm−1. According to previous reports [34–37], the bands at 1593 cm−1 and 1408 cm−1 can be attributed to bidentate nitrates; the band at 1272 cm−1 is related to bridge nitrates; the band at 1369 cm−1 corresponds to monodentate nitrates; and the bands at 1602 cm−1 and 1615 cm−1 are attributed to adsorbed NO2. From Fig. 13, it can be seen that with increasing temperature, the types of adsorbed species on the surface of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst change significantly compared to the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst. In Fig. 13(b), the peak intensity corresponding to the bridge nitrate (1272 cm−1) gradually decreases with increasing temperature, while the bands for monodentate nitrate (1369 cm−1) and bidentate nitrate (1408 cm−1) remain relatively stable, which is consistent with the fact that monodentate and bidentate nitrates are more thermally stable than bridge nitrates. For the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst (as shown in Fig. 13(b)), the peak intensity and trend of the adsorbed NO2 bands (1602 cm−1 and 1615 cm−1) are similar to those of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst, which is related to the role of NO oxidation. The intensity of the monodentate band at 1369 cm−1 is significantly higher, appearing at 25°C and showing a trend of increasing peak intensity with temperature. In addition, a new thermally stable bidentate nitrate band (1408 cm−1) appears in the spectrum of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst. These changes suggest that the addition of citric acid promotes the adsorption of NOx species on the surface of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst. In conclusion, citric acid modification promotes the adsorption of NOx species on the surface of CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalysts and the formation of monodentate and bidentate nitrate species, which is beneficial for promoting the NH3-SCR reaction and improving the catalyst's denitration performance. 3.6.3 NO+O2+NH3 co-adsorption To understand the microscopic process of the NH3-SCR reaction on CeO2-WO3/TiO2-n catalysts, in-situ NO+O2+NH3 co-adsorption experiments were performed on CeO2-WO3/TiO2-n catalysts under a heating rate of 5 °C/min, with each temperature point maintained for 15 min. The results are shown in Fig. 14. For the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst (as shown in Fig. 14(a)), it can be observed that after the mixed gas is introduced, bidentate nitrates (1552 cm−1), bridge nitrates (1272 cm−1), Lewis acid sites (1141 cm−1), Brønsted acid sites (1625 cm−1), and adsorbed NO2 (1602 cm−1) can all be detected. When the temperature is raised to 100°C, monodentate nitrates (1369 cm−1) begin to appear, and as the temperature increases, the peak intensity of the monodentate nitrates gradually increases while the peak intensity of the bridge nitrates (1272 cm−1) gradually decreases. At the same time, the intensities of the Lewis acid site (1141 cm−1) and Brønsted acid site (1625 cm−1) gradually decrease, indicating that at higher temperatures, this phenomenon may be due to the partial decomposition of bridged nitrate or its transformation at Lewis acid sites and Brønsted acid sites following the temperature increase. From Fig. 14(b), it can be seen that the in-situ co-adsorption DRIFTs results for CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst are similar to those of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst, but the signal peak intensities for each species show more pronounced changes with temperature, indicating that the release of the catalyst's surface active sites is faster. Additionally, in Fig. 14(b), the peak intensities for each species are higher, and a new signal peak for bidentate nitrate (1408 cm−1) appears, indicating that the surface of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst has a richer variety of nitrate species. In both Fig. 14(a) and Fig. 14(b), a signal peak for adsorbed NO2 appears, indicating that both CeO2-WO3/TiO2 and CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalysts can adsorb NO+O2 to generate adsorbed NO2 due to the unpaired electrons of the NO molecules, which means that the NH3-SCR reaction on the surface of CeO2-WO3/TiO2-n catalysts follows the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism. Meanwhile, NH3 molecules adsorbed on the Lewis acid sites on the surface of both CeO2-WO3/TiO2 and CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalysts undergo slow reactions with gas-phase NO, indicating that the NH3-SCR reaction on CeO2-WO3/TiO2-n catalysts also follows the Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism. Based on Fig. 14(a) and 14(b), it is concluded that the NH3-SCR reaction on the surface of CeO2-WO3/TiO2-n catalysts follows both L-H and E-R mechanisms, with the L-H mechanism being dominant. 3.6.4 Reaction between NO and the pre-adsorbed NH3 species To investigate the NH3-SCR reaction mechanism on CeO2-WO3/TiO2 and CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalysts, in-situ co-adsorption experiments of NO+O2 were conducted on these two catalysts pre-adsorbed with NH3 at 400℃, as shown in Fig. 15. For the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst (Fig. 15(a)), the signals corresponding to Lewis acid sites (1141 cm−1) and Brønsted acid sites (1388, 1420, 1594, and 1625 cm−1) can be observed at 400 ℃ when NH3 is saturated. Upon turning off the NH3 gas and introducing a NO+O2 gas mixture, several interesting phenomena were noted: (1) after introducing the NO+O2 mixture for 10 min, the signals associated with NH3 adsorption began to diminish and completely disappeared after 20 min; (2) bidentate nitrates (1408 and 1593 cm−1) and monodentate nitrates (1369 cm−1) related to adsorbed NOx species appeared at 10 min, while bridged nitrates (1205 and 1272 cm−1) and adsorbed NO2 (1615 cm−1) appeared at 20 min. Fig. 15(b) shows that the in-situ co-adsorption DRIFT spectra of NO+O2 on the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst pre-adsorbed with NH3 are very similar to those of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst. These results show that both CeO2-WO3/TiO2 and CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalysts can adsorb NO+O2 to form adsorbed NOx species due to the presence of unpaired electrons in NO molecules. The NH3-SCR reaction on the surface of CeO2-WO3/TiO2 and CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalysts follows the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism. 3.6.5 Reaction among NH3 and pre-adsorbed NOx species On the other hand, the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 and CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalysts pre-adsorbed with NO+O2 were subjected to in-situ NH3 adsorption at 400 ℃, as shown in Fig. 16. When the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst (Fig. 16(a)) was saturated with NO+O2 at 400 ℃, characteristic bands of bidentate nitrates (1408 and 1593 cm−1), bridged nitrates (1205 and 1272 cm−1), monodentate nitrates (1369 cm−1), and adsorbed NO2 (1615 cm−1) were detected. Upon switching off the NO+O2 gas mixture and introducing NH3 gas, no infrared signal corresponding to adsorbed NH3 species was detected throughout the test. This suggests that the adsorption affinity of NOx on the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 and CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalysts is stronger than that for NH3, so the pre-adsorbed NO+O2 inhibits NH3 adsorption on the catalyst surface. However, it was noted that after 50 min of NH3 introduction, the band of bridged nitrate at 1272 cm−1 weakened and eventually disappeared. As time progressed further, the intensities of the bands at 1593 and 1615 cm−1 continued to decrease, while those at 1369 and 1408 cm−1 remained relatively stable. Fig. 16(b) shows that the NH3 DRIFT spectra for the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst pre-adsorbed with NO+O2 are very similar to those of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst. These experimental results suggest that the NOx components adsorbed on both catalysts react slowly with gaseous NH3 molecules, indicating the presence of the Eley-Rideal (E-R) mechanism in NH3-SCR reactions over these catalysts. In conjunction with Figs. 15 and 16, we conclude that the NH3-SCR reaction on the surfaces of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 and CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalysts follows both the L-H and E-R mechanisms, with the L-H mechanism being predominant. 3.7 Catalytic activity of catalysts The effect of different citric acid addition amounts on the denitration performance of CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalysts is shown in Fig. 17. The results indicate that after citric acid modification, the catalyst's denitration performance is significantly improved, with a widened temperature range and increased N2 selectivity. As the amount of citric acid added increases, the catalytic performance shows a trend of first improving and then declining. Among them, the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst exhibits the best NH3-SCR performance, with the highest NO conversion rate reaching 98.63 %, and the denitration efficiency remains above 90 % in the temperature range of 217–517°C, which is about 40°C wider compared to the unmodified catalyst. Furthermore, the N2 selectivity of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst can remain above 90 % within 550°C, with N2 selectivity reaching 100 % in the 200–300°C range. After 300°C, N2 selectivity gradually starts to decrease due to the excessive oxidation of some NH3 during the catalytic process, accompanied by the side reaction generating N2O. The addition of citric acid can slow down the decline of N2 selectivity at high temperatures. Similarly, with increasing citric acid addition, N2 selectivity gradually improves, with the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst showing the best N2 selectivity. When the citric acid addition exceeds 6 %, the N2 selectivity begins to decline. To evaluate the stability of the catalytic activity of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst, its performance was continuously monitored for 100 h at 300 ℃. Denitrification efficiency was recorded at two-hour intervals. The results are presented in Fig. 18. For the first 34 h, the catalytic activity remained stable at about 93 %. From 36 h onward, a decline in denitrification efficiency was observed, reaching 82.1 % by 76 h. This level was maintained until the conclusion of the test. The SO2 and H2O resistance performance of CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalysts before and after citric acid addition is shown in Fig. 19. In Fig. 19(a), after the catalyst's denitration performance is stabilized for 5 h at 300°C, 60 ppm SO2 is introduced. The denitration efficiency of CeO2-WO3/TiO2 and CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalysts decreases to 84.5 % and 87.4 %, respectively, and then levels off. After stopping the SO2 introduction, the denitration efficiency begins to recover, with the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst restoring a denitration efficiency of 98.22 %, showing excellent SO2 resistance. Fig. 19(b) examines the stability of the catalyst's denitration performance in the presence of both SO2 and H2O. After stabilizing the denitration performance for 5 h at 300°C, 60 ppm SO2 and 5 % H2O are introduced. The denitration efficiency of CeO2-WO3/TiO2 and CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalysts decreases to 81 % and 86.5 %, respectively, and then levels off. After stopping the introduction of SO2 and H2O, the denitration efficiency gradually recovered to 94 % and 97 %, respectively. The results show that, compared to the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst, the catalyst modified with citric acid exhibits superior SO2 and H2O resistance performance. 4 Conclusion In summary, we prepared a series of citric acid-modified CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalysts via the co-precipitation method to explore the specific effects and mechanisms of citric acid modification on the denitration performance of CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalysts. These samples were studied in detail using physicochemical characterization techniques, and the following important conclusions were obtained: (1) Citric acid modification helps to improve the denitration performance of CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalysts. The denitration conversion rates of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst are higher than 80 % and 90 % at 205–543°C and 217–517°C, respectively, while the catalyst also shows good N2 selectivity and excellent resistance to water and sulfur. (2) The addition of 6 % citric acid inhibits the lattice growth of CeO2 and WO3 most effectively. The complexation of citric acid with Ce and W significantly refines the size of the catalyst's active components, leading to more uniform dispersion and an increase in the catalyst's specific surface area. (3) Citric acid modification facilitates the sufficient atomic-level contact between CeO2 and WO3, promoting electron transfer between active elements, thereby increasing the content of Ce3+ and W5+ on the catalyst surface, generating more surface-active oxygen, increasing the oxygen vacancy content, and creating more adsorption sites for NOx and NH3, which significantly improves the catalyst's redox performance. (4) NH3-TPD, NO-TPD and In-situ DRIFTs results indicate that citric acid modification provides more acidic sites for the catalyst, while the acidic sites on the surface of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst significantly enhance the adsorption of NH3 and adsorb more NOx species, which is beneficial for improving the denitration performance of the NH3-SCR reaction. On the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 and CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalysts, the NH3-SCR reaction follows both L-H and E-R mechanisms, but the L-H mechanism is predominant. Furthermore, citric acid modification does not alter the reaction mechanism of NH3-SCR on the surface of the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst. coredata.dc:description: This study investigates the performance regulation and mechanism of citric acid on the CeO2-WO3/TiO2 catalyst. The CeO2-WO3/TiO2-6 % catalyst exhibits a denitrification conversion rate exceeding 90 % within the temperature range of 217–517°C, with a significantly broader working temperature window. Additionally, it demonstrates excellent N2 selectivity and superior resistance to water and sulfur. Through a series of characterization methods, the physical and chemical properties of the catalyst were analyzed. The results indicate that the complexation of an appropriate amount of citric acid with Ce and W can refine the grain size, increase the specific surface area, and provide more acidic sites, significantly improving the adsorption properties. Moreover, the addition of citric acid during the preparation process can promote the electron transfer between active elements, increase the oxygen vacancy content, and enhance the catalyst's redox properties.
